title: Primary school teacher suffers horrific burns after laser hair removal goes horribly wrong
text:
A Melbourne woman fears her legs may be permanently scarred for life after a recent beauty salon treatment went horribly wrong.

Primary school teacher Sara Neep, 34, claims a $1000 laser hair removal left her legs swollen with horrific burns and blisters.

She still bears the scars after five weeks of medication and cortisone cream.

'I started losing feeling in my legs and my feet,' Ms Neep told Nine News.

Sara Neep started losing feeling in her legs after a beauty treatment went horribly wrong

She contacted The Skin Boutique in Elwood in the city's inner south afterwards but was told it was a normal reaction.

She sought a second opinion from a dermatologist, who told it was 'definitely a burn.'

Ms Neep must keep her legs covered for another three months and has requested a refund and compensation for medical costs.

'I'm a little bit terrified to let anyone ever touch my skin again,' she said.

The salon said in a written statement all reasonable care was under taken by staff.

Ms Neep claims the $1000 laser hair removal left her legs with horrific burns and blisters

It added Ms Neep signed a written consent and was warned of the prospect of the 'recognised' complication she suffered, a claim the customer denies.

'I filled out a form, but they didn't sit down with me with the form and even read through it,' Ms Neep said.

Daily Mail Australia has contacted the salon for further comment.

Laser treatment risks Scars, burns and pigmentary changes Disfigurement Increase in hair growth Permanent injuries and infections Source: Choice

Ms Neep's experience prompted a warning from dermatologists for consumers looking to have laser treatment to do their research into the salon, the devices they use and ensure the treatment is suitable for their hair and skin type.

The non-surgical cosmetic health services industry generates over $1 billion each year according to a Committee on the Health Care Complaints Commission Report in 2018.

Melbourne woman Sara Neep (pictured) must keep her legs covered for another three months

The Victorian Health Complaints Commissioner received 26 complaints about laser treatments last year, while NSW Fair Trading received a staggering 287 complaints about beauty services in 2017.

'I see a lot of scars, burns and pigmentary changes; 'stripes' of white or brown,' The Australasian College of Dermatologists Dr Ritu Gupta told Choice earlier this year.

'If people are treated at incorrect doses, it can also cause an increase in hair growth rather than a decrease. Or it might turn the hair white, so it will never respond to any form of laser or light therapy hair removal. That's just the tip of the iceberg.'
description: A Melbourne woman fears her legs my be permanently scarred for life after a recent laser hair removal treatment at a inner city beauty salon went horribly wrong.
authors: Kylie Stevens For Daily Mail Australia
